entry.title: Despite numerous attempts to discredit and and weaken SB20-217,...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

Despite numerous attempts to discredit and and weaken SB20-217, the Law Enforcement Integrity Act, the vast majority of Coloradans SUPPORT our bi-partisan reform efforts.

“More than two-thirds of respondents — 69% — said they approve of Senate Bill 217, a sweeping police reform measure passed into law by the state legislature.”

The Denver Post

A new poll provides further evidence that Donald Trump and Cory Gardner are in trouble in Colorado. But it also offers fresh insight into how Coloradans generally view the Black Lives Matter moveme…

denverpost.com

Colorado voters support police reform law, haven’t heard of QAnon, poll finds

A new poll provides further evidence that Donald Trump and Cory Gardner are in trouble in Colorado. But it also offers fresh insight into how Coloradans generally view the Black Lives Matter moveme…A new poll provides further evidence that Donald Trump and Cory Gardner are in trouble in Colorado. But it also offers fresh insight into how Coloradans generally view the Black Lives Matter moveme…

entry.title: “(Revenue) has been trending in a positive direction, but I...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“(Revenue) has been trending in a positive direction, but I think we remain concerned about the fall, the winter and into next year, and the ability for particularly our small businesses to remain open and to sustain themselves through this very difficult time period,” said Brendan Hanlon, the city’s chief financial officer. “Because although we have seen a lifting of the most severe public health restrictions, restrictions remain in place for a very good reason.”

Denverite

The city’s 2021 spending plan is filled with cuts to bridge an estimated $190 million gapThe police department alone would lose $25 million.The city’s 2021 spending plan is filled with cuts to bridge an estimated $190 million gapThe police department alone would lose $25 million.See more at DENVERITE.COM

entry.title: I am so honored to be named this year’s Denver Democrat of the...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

I am so honored to be named this year’s Denver Democrat of the Year! Thank you to all of you who support me every single day - nothing is achieved alone! Purchase your ticket today (https://rb.gy/k3x7gi) and join the celebration! Denver Democrats

entry.title: Make no mistake, payouts like these are happening across the...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

Make no mistake, payouts like these are happening across the country and costing the taxpayers millions of dollars. Massive change is necessary and it’s coming.

In the aftermath of the botched police raid in which Ms. Taylor was killed, the city also agreed to institute changes aimed at preventing future deaths by officers.

nytimes.com

Breonna Taylor’s Family to Receive $12 Million Settlement From City of Louisville

In the aftermath of the botched police raid in which Ms. Taylor was killed, the city also agreed to institute changes aimed at preventing future deaths by officers.In the aftermath of the botched police raid in which Ms. Taylor was killed, the city also agreed to institute changes aimed at preventing future deaths by officers.

entry.title: “No one should be penalized for the way their hair grows...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“No one should be penalized for the way their hair grows naturally out of their heads,” said Herod, who is a Black woman. “We should support and celebrate our diversity, our cultural diversity and we should ensure that Colorado is in place to protect folks who are being discriminated against.”

The Colorado law also redefines the characteristics of discrimination to include “hairtexture, hairtype, or a protective hairstyle that is commonly or historically associated with race.”

The Colorado Sun

The Colorado law also redefines the characteristics of discrimination to include “hairtexture, hairtype, or a protective hairstyle that is commonly or historically associated with race."

coloradosun.com

Colorado’s hair discrimination law — the CROWN Act — goes into effect

The Colorado law also redefines the characteristics of discrimination to include “hairtexture, hairtype, or a protective hairstyle that is commonly or historically associated with race."The Colorado law also redefines the characteristics of discrimination to include “hairtexture, hairtype, or a protective hairstyle that is commonly or historically associated with race."

entry.title: “I hope that this bill empowers our young people to be who...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“I hope that this bill empowers our young people to be who they are but also to know that they can push and demand equality,” Herod said.

The Denver Post

A Colorado law aimed at protecting workers and students from discrimination against race-based hair traits went into effect Monday.

denverpost.com

Colorado’s CROWN Act, banning natural hair discrimination, goes into effect

A Colorado law aimed at protecting workers and students from discrimination against race-based hair traits went into effect Monday.A Colorado law aimed at protecting workers and students from discrimination against race-based hair traits went into effect Monday.

entry.title: “Developmentally, remote learning, that’s really not...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Developmentally, remote learning, that’s really not preschool,” she said. “The whole point of preschool is that children learn social-emotional skills and they develop executive function skills, and that is not done in front of a computer.”

Colorado Politics

Twice in his young life, Finn Jillson has been hospitalized with the seasonal flu. Finn has asthma. A few years ago, he ended up in an ambulance on his way

coloradopolitics.com

Why Denver isn’t offering virtual preschool in a pandemic — and why it might in the future

entry.title: Want to track your ballot and ensure that it has been counted?...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

Want to track your ballot and ensure that it has been counted? Now, all Coloradans can sign up for BallotTrace and do just that!

A few counties across Colorado have been allowing voters to track the life of their ballots, and beginning with the upcoming election voters in all 64 counties will be able to do so, Secretary of S…

denverpost.com

All Colorado voters will be able to track their ballots in fall election

A few counties across Colorado have been allowing voters to track the life of their ballots, and beginning with the upcoming election voters in all 64 counties will be able to do so, Secretary of S…A few counties across Colorado have been allowing voters to track the life of their ballots, and beginning with the upcoming election voters in all 64 counties will be able to do so, Secretary of S…

entry.title: "The Denver Police Department is the costliest part of the...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

"The Denver Police Department is the costliest part of the Department of Safety, which usually ranks as the most expensive city agency. And spending on law enforcement continues to rise, budget documents show. Last year, taxpayers spent over $268 million on policing compared to $179 million in 2009. To jail people, Denver spent over $156 million last year compared to $94 million 10 years prior. As of June 15, DPD counted 1,586 sworn officers, 140 more than in 2009."

Denverite

As people protest for change, here’s where ten years of massive Denver police and jail spending has gotten usSome of the most innovative programs — the ones that advocates and officials say have reduced conflict — are the least-funded and aren’t permanent.As people protest for change, here’s where ten years of massive Denver police and jail spending has gotten usSome of the most innovative programs — the ones that advocates and officials say have reduced conflict — are the least-funded and aren’t permanent.See more at DENVERITE.COM

entry.title: “There are a lot of dope Black artists. There are a lot of...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“There are a lot of dope Black artists. There are a lot of dope female artists. There’s a lot of super, super badass transgender and nonbinary artists,” Gram said. “And the proportions of artists involved should be reflective of the true demographics of creatives and artists in the city.”

Denverite

The mural group is fundraising to be able to pay artists who are getting their chance to paint during this week’s festival

denverite.com

An all-Black mural group fights for their place at CRUSH Walls — and in the broader art world

The mural group is fundraising to be able to pay artists who are getting their chance to paint during this week’s festivalThe mural group is fundraising to be able to pay artists who are getting their chance to paint during this week’s festival

entry.title: “The sanctioned campsites would exist on a plaza between Sonny...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“The sanctioned campsites would exist on a plaza between Sonny Lawson Park and the Blair-Caldwell Library along Welton Street. Campers would have about 14,000 square feet that would hold 33 tents and a maximum of 40 people, according to the Colorado Village Collaborative, which would manage the site.

People experiencing homelessness camp in this area already, though it’s technically illegal.”

Denverite

People would be allowed to sleep outdoors on a strip of city-owned land between Sonny Lawson Park and the Blair-Caldwell Library.

denverite.com

Mayor Hancock proposes sanctioned campsite in Five Points where unhoused people already camp

People would be allowed to sleep outdoors on a strip of city-owned land between Sonny Lawson Park and the Blair-Caldwell Library.People would be allowed to sleep outdoors on a strip of city-owned land between Sonny Lawson Park and the Blair-Caldwell Library.

entry.title: “Colorado officials announced Tuesday that the state is...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Colorado officials announced Tuesday that the state is partnering with Apple and Google to allow people to download an application on their smartphones or opt into a service that can anonymously inform them if they have been exposed to the coronavirus.”

The Colorado

The system will work in the background of people's everyday lives if they choose to opt-in to the service or download the app

coloradosun.com

Colorado partners with Apple, Google to allow for coronavirus exposure notification on cellphones

The system will work in the background of people's everyday lives if they choose to opt-in to the service or download the appThe system will work in the background of people's everyday lives if they choose to opt-in to the service or download the app

entry.title: “Kelly Ferro is a busy mom on her way to the post office:...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Kelly Ferro is a busy mom on her way to the post office: leather mini-backpack, brunet topknot, turquoise pedicure with a matching ombré manicure. A hairdresser from Kenosha, Wis., Ferro didn’t vote in 2016 but has since become a strong supporter of Donald Trump. “Why does the news hate the President so much?” TIME

Democracy relies on an informed public responding to real-life facts. But a growing number of Americans are untethered from reality.

time.com

How Conspiracy Theories Are Shaping the 2020 Election—and Shaking the Foundation of American Democracy

Democracy relies on an informed public responding to real-life facts. But a growing number of Americans are untethered from reality.Democracy relies on an informed public responding to real-life facts. But a growing number of Americans are untethered from reality.

entry.title: “Later this month, help is coming — in the form of a giant...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Later this month, help is coming — in the form of a giant RV gutted and transformed into a child care center with cribs, books and toys. The vehicle, named “Honey” after the teddy bear painted on its side, will spend time parked outside of Aspen Center locations and other substance abuse and mental health treatment centers throughout the Denver area.

If there is enough money to pull it off, a second day care on wheels will circulate among treatment centers in the San Luis Valley, an area hit hard by the opioid crisis. “

The Colorado Sun

The first-of-its-kind program will send RVs renovated as child care classrooms to drug and mental health centers in Denver and the San Luis Valley.

coloradosun.com

Lack of child care prevents moms from getting drug treatment in Colorado. Here comes “RV Honey.”

The first-of-its-kind program will send RVs renovated as child care classrooms to drug and mental health centers in Denver and the San Luis Valley.The first-of-its-kind program will send RVs renovated as child care classrooms to drug and mental health centers in Denver and the San Luis Valley.

entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“The annual mural fest returns with pandemic safety precautions in place. Here are the details, plus a chat with artist Hiero Veiga.”

Crush Walls, Denver's annual graffiti and street art festival, is back in 2020 with 100 artists and new coronavirus pandemic guidelines.

theknow.denverpost.com

entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

The Denver Post

The Colorado Health Foundation commissioned two polling groups, one left-leaning and one right-leaning, to survey more than 2,000 adults living in Colorado about how the pandemic had affected them,…

entry.title: "While it may not feel as urgent as an eviction notice or...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

"While it may not feel as urgent as an eviction notice or the fear of food scarcity, the devastation of the arts and culture scene due to the coronavirus pandemic portends long-term ripple effects.

The arts in Colorado are a powerful economic driver as well as a defining aspect of our community and fuel for our humanity. The industry, from the tiniest experimental theater to the grandest outdoor music venue, is experiencing cancellations, postponements, layoffs and unsustainable revenue losses."

The Colorado Sun

Local philanthropists are working on grants to support artists, venues and groups. But one study suggests reviving a massive, national New Deal-like program.

coloradosun.com

Coronavirus killed 59,179 arts jobs in Colorado and crippled key economic and cultural engines. Can they be revived?

Local philanthropists are working on grants to support artists, venues and groups. But one study suggests reviving a massive, national New Deal-like program.Local philanthropists are working on grants to support artists, venues and groups. But one study suggests reviving a massive, national New Deal-like program.

entry.title: Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have community support for this work. We all have a story to tell. Our stories are our strength and our voices will be heard.

"Forget political stereotypes: This history-making legislator is unapologetically progressive, is insistent that state government can be bipartisan (even now), and wants to transform the criminal justice system. And that's just the start of her ambitions.”

- 5280 Magazine
